binding.name: note
binding.literal: Musa textilis from the Musaceae family. Manila hemp is not to be confused with true hemp from Cannabis sativa.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Species of the Acacia genus belong to the subfamily Mimosoideae of the Fabaceae family (formerly known as the Leguminosae). The genus Acacia is currently undergoing taxonomic re-evaluation (following cladistic analyses) and it is likely that in the future the term Acacia will only be applicable to Acacia species in Australia, not in the rest of the world such as in Africa, the Near East, southern Asia and the Americas. This information will be updated when the new list is published.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Species of the Acacia genus belong to the subfamily Mimosoideae of the Fabaceae family (formerly known as the Leguminosae). The genus Acacia is currently undergoing taxonomic re-evaluation (following cladistic analyses) and it is likely that in the future the term Acacia will only be applicable to Acacia species in Australia, not in the rest of the world such as in Africa, the Near East, southern Asia and the Americas. This information will be updated when the new list is published.

This information will be updated when the new list is published.

The genus Acacia is currently undergoing taxonomic re-evaluation (following cladistic analyses) and it is likely that in the future the term Acacia will only be applicable to Acacia species in Australia, not in the rest of the world such as in Africa, the Near East, southern Asia and the Americas. This information will be updated when the new list is published.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Species in the Aconitum genus belong to the family Ranunculaceae.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The acorn is the fruit in the form of a nut of the oak tree from the genus Quercus in the Fagaceae family.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Acrylic yarn is a thread now commonly used instead of wool for knitting, embroidery and decorative weaving.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Guibou in the subfamily Caesalpinioideae of the family Fabaceae (syn. Leguminosae). Former botanical synomyms include: Copaifera coleosperma Benth., Copaiva coleosperma (Benth.) Kuntze, Copaifera hymenaeifolia (Moric.) J. Leon

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Afzelia is a genus in the subfamily Caesalpinioideae of the family Fabaceae (syn. Leguminosae).

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Afzelia is a genus in the subfamily Caesalpinioideae of the family Fabaceae (syn. Leguminosae).

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Agave is a genus belonging in the Agavaceae family. It is not related to the Aloe genus which belongs to a different family, the Aloeaceae.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Agave is a genus belonging in the Agavaceae family. It is not related to the Aloe genus which belongs to a different family, the Aloeaceae.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: In this thesaurus, the term refers to man-made aggregates rather than natural ones. See also BRECCIA and CONGLOMERATE.

binding.name: note
binding.literal:
Alabaster is calcium sulphate, but the word 'alabaster' in Egyptian, Near Eastern and Greek archaeology has been commonly misused for objects which in fact are made of calcite (calcium carbonate). Thus when searching for alabaster objects, users are recommended to search for Material 'calcite' as well as 'alabaster'.
N.B.
The suggestion by some authorities to use the term 'travertine' for Egyptian alabaster (ie. calcite) is not generally accepted.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The genus Alnus belongs in the Betulaceae family. Species of alder, Alnus spp., will vary depending on their geographical distribution e.g. in Europe, North America or temperate Asia.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The genus Alnus belongs in the Betulaceae family. Species of alder, Alnus spp., will vary depending on their geographical distribution e.g. in Europe, North America or temperate Asia.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The genus Alnus belongs in the Betulaceae family. Species of alder, Alnus spp., will vary depending on their geographical distribution e.g. in Europe, North America or temperate Asia.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The genus Alnus belongs in the Betulaceae family. Species of alder, Alnus spp., will vary depending on their geographical distribution e.g. in Europe, North America or temperate Asia.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Medicago sativa L. belongs to the Fabaceae family (formerly known as Leguminosae).

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Species of the Prosopis genus belong to the subfamily Mimosoideae of the Fabaceae family (formerly known as Leguminosae).

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Species of the Prosopis genus belong to the subfamily Mimosoideae of the Fabaceae family (formerly known as Leguminosae).

binding.name: note
binding.literal:
The term refers to the nut.
Prunus dulcis, syn. Prunus amygdalus Batsch., Amygdalus communis L., Amygdalus dulcis Mill. The genus Prunus belongs to Rosaceae family.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Aloe is a genus belonging in the Aloeaceae family. It is not related to the Agave genus which belongs to a different family, the Agavaceae.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Aloe is a genus belonging in the Aloeaceae family. It is not related to the Agave genus which belongs to a different family, the Agavaceae.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Aloe is a genus belonging in the Aloeaceae family. It is not related to the Agave genus which belongs to a different family, the Agavaceae.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Aloe is a genus belonging in the Aloeaceae family. It is not related to the Agave genus which belongs to a different family, the Agavaceae.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Aloe is a genus belonging in the Aloeaceae family. It is not related to the Agave genus which belongs to a different family, the Agavaceae.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Aeschynomene elaphroxylon Taub. (synonym Herminiera elaphroxylon Guill. & Perr.) belongs to the Fabaceae family (formerly known as the Leguminosae). Subfamily Papilionoideae

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Pterocarpus indicus Willd. belongs to the Fabaceae family (formerly known as the Leguminosae).

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Agave americana L belongs to the Agavaceae family. It is not related to the Aloe genus which belongs to a different family, the Aloeaceae.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Agave americana L belongs to the Agavaceae family. It is not related to the Aloe genus which belongs to a different family, the Aloeaceae

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Fagaceae family. Quercus rubra - Syn.: Quercus borealis Michx. f. var. maxima (Marsh.) Ashe, Quercus maxima (Marsh.) Ashe, Quercus falcata Michx.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term is defined as material produced by the animal, not an integral part of the animal.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: This term and its Narrow Terms are for combinations of constitutents (which would be too numerous to enter individually) such as 'leg', or for the whole animal, or for unspecified matter from a named animal. It is not intended to reflect 'tissue' in a strict biological sense.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Bixaceae family. Common names for the tree include achiote, anato, annatto, arnato, bija, bijol, bixa, lipstick tree, roucou

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Areca is a genus of about 50 species of single-stemmed palms in the family Arecaceae, found in humid tropical forests e.g. Areca catechu, the areca nut palm. Special note: It should not be confused with Chrysalidocarpus lutescens, syn. Dypsis lutescens (golden cane palm, or yellow butterfly palm) from the Arecaceae family which is often referred to as the 'areca palm' although it is not in that genus.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Areca is a genus of about 50 species of single-stemmed palms in the family Arecaceae, found in humid tropical forests e.g. Areca catechu, the areca nut palm. Special note: It should not be confused with Chrysalidocarpus lutescens, syn. Dypsis lutescens (golden cane palm, or yellow butterfly palm) from the Arecaceae family which is often referred to as the 'areca palm' although it is not in that genus.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Areca is a genus of about 50 species of single-stemmed palms in the family Arecaceae, found in humid tropical forests e.g. Areca catechu, the areca nut palm. Special note: It should not be confused with Chrysalidocarpus lutescens, syn. Dypsis lutescens (golden cane palm, or yellow butterfly palm) from the Arecaceae family which is often referred to as the 'areca palm' although it is not in that genus.

Dypsis lutescens (golden cane palm, or yellow butterfly palm) from the Arecaceae family which is often referred to as the 'areca palm' although it is not in that genus.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Argania spinosa (L.) Skeels (formerly Sideroxylon spinosum); Sapotaceae family. Uses: leaves etc for food & fodder; wood for fuelwood and charcoal; trees used for erosion control.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Medemia argun (C.Mart.)Württemb. Arecaceae family. Uses: FOOD(Infructescences); MATERIALS(Fibres, Wood).

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Medemia argun (C.Mart.)Württemb. Arecaceae family. Uses: FOOD(Infructescences); MATERIALS(Fibres, Wood).

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Maranta arundinacea is from the Marantaceae family. The 'term 'arrowroot' is used for other plants too, so the type of arrowroot and its context must be taken into account when choosing the correct scientific terms. For example: Zamia pumila L. (Zamiaceae family), Florida arrowroot, produces a commercial starch. The term 'arrowroot' is sometimes used in more generalised way today to describe any starch, including that from tapoica and from kudzu flour which derives from Pueraria lobata (Fabaceae family). Canna indica L. / Canna edulis (Cannaceae family) also yields "arrowroot". In addition, the term may be even more general and largely non-botanical i.e. a root used for arrows.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Maranta arundinacea is from the Marantaceae family. The 'term 'arrowroot' is used for other plants too, so the type of arrowroot and its context must be taken into account when choosing the correct scientific terms. For example: Zamia pumila L. (Zamiaceae family), Florida arrowroot, produces a commercial starch. The term 'arrowroot' is sometimes used in more generalised way today to describe any starch, including that from tapoica and from kudzu flour which derives from Pueraria lobata (Fabaceae family). Canna indica L. / Canna edulis (Cannaceae family) also yields "arrowroot". In addition, the term may be even more general and largely non-botanical i.e. a root used for arrows.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Arum species, i.e. arums are in the Araceae family. There are other genera in this family which are called arum lily e.g. Zantedeschia spp.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Rosa damascena Mill., and Rosa centifolia L. are from the Rosaceae family.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Astrocaryum vulgare Mart. belongs to the Arecaceae family.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Cu3(CO3)2(OH)2, Copper Carbonate Hydroxide This is an intense blue colour.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Rawhide strips used in hunting bags, for example.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: See also IVORY - although not the same material as baleen or whalebone, the terms have not always been applied correctly.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Bamboos belong to the grass family Poaceae, subfamily Bambusoideae, tribe Bambuseae.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term is used generically to cover fibre from both ito-basho ("thread banana") plants, the true Japanese Fibre Banana - Musa balbisiana (synonym Musa liukiuensis) and fibre from the edible banana species (Musa basjoo). Bashofu is the Japanese name of the banana fibre cloth.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Barkcloth (bark cloth) is beaten or felted bark. If the name of the specific bark is known, the specific term (e.g. acacia bark) is entered. The Object Name barkcloth should be only be entered if the object is a piece of barkcloth with no known use, e.g. a sample. If the object is, e.g. an apron, that term is the Object Name. The term barkcloth is always recorded in the Description.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: This is not a recognised scientific term.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term refers to bast fibre.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Spanish term for thin-stemmed plants such as rattan, and for a particular twining shrub.

binding.name: note
binding.literal:
The term refers to a coinage metal consisting essentially of silver and copper, with silver typically in the range 10-30%.
For Greek and Roman coins historically referred to as billon or base silver, enter 'base silver' in Description, 'silver' in Materials and 'base' in Materials Comment.
'Billon' is particularly associated with the coinage of medieval and early modern Europe, where it formed a recognised third level of currency, alongside gold and fine silver, used for low denominations. It is also known as 'black money' and 'base-silver'. From the 16th century it came to be replaced by copper coinage, but did not disappear completely until the 19th century.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Use for the whole egg, or the contents of the shell; for the eggshell, enter BIRD EGGSHELL.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Leaf from the Scared Bo (bodhi) tree.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The form of the bone, eg: 'skull', 'femur', etc. should be entered in the Description field.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Borax a natural mineral (sodium borate) which, when mixed with water, is used as a flux by metalsmiths to facilitate the soldering together of jewellery components.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term copper alloy should be searched for full retrievals on objects made or bronze or brass. This is because bronze and brass have at times been used interchangeably in the old documentation, and copper alloy is the Broad Term of both. In addition, the public may refer to certain collections by their popular name, such as 'The Benin Bronzes' most of which are actually made of brass.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term refers to the fruit.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term copper alloy should be searched for full retrievals on objects made or bronze or brass. This is because bronze and brass have at times been used interchangeably in the old documentation, and copper alloy is the Broad Term of both. In addition, the public may refer to certain collections by their popular name, such as 'The Benin Bronzes' most of which are actually made of brass.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term may also have been used, incorrectly, for the AMERICAN BISON HORN; seach under both terms.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: See also records with BISON SKIN.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Terms referring to Buffalo may have been used incorrectly for the American Bison.

binding.name: note
binding.literal:
This term is taken to include the banded variety of stone alternatively known as 'Egyptian alabaster' or 'calcite-alabaster', a crystalline form of calcium carbonate.
The suggestion by some authorities to use the term 'travertine' for Egyptian alabaster (ie. calcite) is not generally accepted.
'Spar' is an archaic term referring to a well-formed, generally transparent or translucent crystal referring to either feldspar, fluorspar, or dog-tooth spar (ie. calcite).

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term refers to South American textiles made of alpaca wool, llama wool or vicuna wool. If the precise nature of the wool has been identified, the specific term is entered, e.g. 'alpaca wool'. If there is doubt, the term is entered as. e.g. 'alpaca wool' and qualified with a '?' in the Comment field. If all that is known is 'camelid wool', that term is entered.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term denotes a shield of exoskeleton covering part of the body of certain animals. See also SHELL.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Carbon fibre has a complex composition and can be used and adapted in many ways e.g. as loose/woven carbon filaments with many different weave patterns, or combined with a plastic resin and wound / moulded to form composite materials such as carbon fibre reinforced plastic (also referenced as carbon fibre) to provide a high strength-to-weight ratio material (C.R. Cartwright, 06/04/09).

binding.name: note
binding.literal: 'Cat' terms are used as Broad Terms covering wild cats and the 'great cats' as well as domesticated varieties.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: 'Cat' terms are used as Broad Terms covering wild cats and the 'great cats' as well as domesticated varieties.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: 'Cat' terms are used as Broad Terms covering wild cats and the 'great cats' as well as domesticated varieties.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: 'Cat' terms are used as Broad Terms covering wild cats and the 'great cats' as well as domesticated varieties.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: 'Cat' terms are used as Broad Terms covering wild cats and the 'great cats' as well as domesticated varieties.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Most commonly Cedrela odorata. Not a true cedar.

binding.name: note
binding.literal:
The term 'celluloid' may have been used erroneously in old forms of documentation. The term refers specifically to cellulose nitrate.
In some records where 'celluloid' was recorded in the original Description, the term entered in Material is the higher-level term (Broad Term) 'plastic'.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Belongs to the hydroxy magnesium silicate group of minerals which inludes serpentine, soapstone (talc) and steatite.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term chrysolite has also been used to refer to yellow chrysoberyl (and other yellow stones). It is sometimes also used to refer to gem quality olivine (which is known also as peridot).

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term chrysolite has also been used to refer to yellow chrysoberyl (and other yellow stones). It is sometimes also used to refer to gem quality olivine (which is known also as peridot).

binding.name: note
binding.literal:
In this thesaurus, the term 'clay' refers to the raw material. If deliberately heated, whether in a fire or a kiln, etc. but not sun dried, the Preferred term in Materials is ‘fired clay’, with ‘baked clay’ a Non-Preferred Term, as it was frequently used historically. No Technique term is entered.
N.B. In the Department of Ancient Egypt and Sudan, the Materials terms ‘mud’ and ‘clay’ have been used interchangeably for unfired objects such as bricks. figurines, and vessels.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Ash and partially fused residues from a cola fired furnace or fire.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term refers to a dried flower-bud used as a spice.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Coade Stone is a stoneware manufactured in the 18th Century by Eleanor Coade.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term has not been defined botanically and may be confused with coccoloba (ie. Coccoloba uvifera).

binding.name: note
binding.literal:
The term 'copper alloy' should be searched for full retrievals on objects made or bronze or brass. This is because bronze and brass have at times been used interchangeably in the old documentation, and copper alloy is the Broad Term of both. In addition, the public may refer to certain collections by their popular name, such as 'The Benin Bronzes' most of which are actually made of brass.
The term 'copper alloy' is used in preference to 'billon' (in both Description and Materials) in records for Roman coins.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term refers to preserved or fossilised faeces (or excrement) of an animal or human.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term normally refers to bark from the cork oak tree, but it has also been given the Broad Term WOOD as it is not possible at present to determine the exact material in each individual record.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Although 'carnelian' is the accepted term in mineralogical texts, the Preferred Term reflects accepted curatorial practice in the British Museum.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: This term covers raw cotton as well as the textile.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term refers to the fruit.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The terms DIORITE, GRANITE and SYENITE have been interchanged incorrectly.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: 'Dog' terms are used as Broad Terms covering wild dogs as well as domesticated varieties.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: 'Dog' terms are used as Broad Terms covering wild dogs as well as domesticated varieties.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Dolerite is of basaltic composition, but coarser grained than basalt because it is not extruded as lava from a volcano but intruded into the earth's crust at lesser or greater depths, and therefore cooled more slowly. It is described as an igneous rock.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: scats and pellets and droppings for excrement

binding.name: note
binding.literal: This term has been used interchangeably with TERRACOTTA and with POTTERY.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Use for the whole egg, or the contents of the shell; for the eggshell alone, enter EGGSHELL.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Use the term for the shell only: if the egg is included, enter EGG.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term refers to a synthetic calcium copper silicate pigment, with the mineral name cuprorivaite.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The North American variety is also called MOOSE.

binding.name: note
binding.literal:
The term 'enamel' has not been included as a Narrow term (NT) of 'glass' for practical reasons. Although technically enamel is glass with a lower melting temperature, the way enamel is applied and worked is quite different from glass, and users tend to search separately for objects made of either.
See also 'enamelled' in the Techniques Thesaurus. N.B.
The 'enamel' used in the Iron Age is not true enamel, which is fused by heat. It is heated opaque glass, which was pressed when molten into prepared metal fields or cells, and allowed to cool and harden. For these records, the term 'enamel' is entered in Description, the term 'enamelled' in Technique, but the Material entered is 'glass'. Records for ceramics painted in enamels do not have 'enamel' entered as a Material, but the term is recorded in Description.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: In this thesaurus, the term is restricted to vegetal fibre, and refers to fibrous material; it does not equate with the botanical definition of fibre. For animal fibre, use ANIMAL or its Narrow Terms. For fabric names, see under TEXTILE. The term FIBRE has been used interchangeably with LEAF in some areas of documentation.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term refers to the fruit.

binding.name: note
binding.literal:
In this thesaurus, the term 'clay' refers to the raw material. If deliberately heated, whether in a fire or a kiln, etc. but not sun dried, the Preferred term in Materials is ‘fired clay’, with ‘baked clay’ a Non-Preferred Term, as it was frequently used historically. No Technique term is entered.
In the Department of Ancient Egypt and Sudan: The Materials terms ‘mud’ and ‘clay’ have been used interchangeably for unfired objects such as bricks. figurines, and vessels.
N.B. The term 'fired clay' has been used interchangeably with 'terracotta' and 'earthenware', but the term 'terracotta' is never used for vessels.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: For burnt flint, record burnt in the description, and in the Technique if the burning was deliberate.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Anadonta sp. If uncertain use the broader term mussel shell which acts for both salt and sea water varieties.

binding.name: note
binding.literal:
The term refers to a ceramic composition that has been fused, quenched to form a glass, and granulated. Frits form an important part of the batches used in compounding enamels and glazes.
Dodd, Dictionary of Ceramics (1967)

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term refers to hair with skin.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Gabbro is of basaltic composition, but coarser grained than basalt because it is not extruded as lava from a volcano but intruded into the earth's crust at lesser or greater depths, and therefore cooled more slowly. It is described as an igneous rock.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Yellow marble with red or pink spots or veins. One of the most used marbles in the whole of the Roman Empire, its quarry is located at Chemtou in Tunisia, ancient Numidia, hence its Latin name marmor numidicum.

binding.name: note
binding.literal:
The term 'enamel' has not been included as a Narrow term (NT) of 'glass' for practical reasons. Although technically enamel is glass with a lower melting temperature, the way enamel is applied and worked is quite different from glass, and users tend to search for such objects independently.
Mosaic glass is mostly Hellenistic in date and was created by chopping up rods and fusing them together in a mould of some sort.

binding.name: note
binding.literal:
The term is used for objects with a body made of finely powdered quartz grains fused together with small amounts of alkali and/or lime through partial heating. The bodies are usually colourless but natural impurities give them a brown or greyish tint. Colourants can also be added to give it an artificial colour. It can be modelled by hand, thrown or moulded, and hardens with firing. This material is used in the context of Islamic ceramics where it is described as stonepaste (or fritware).
Glazed composition is related to glass, but glass is formed by completely fusing the ingredients in a liquid melted at high temperature.
This material is also popularly called faience in the contexts of Ancient Egypt and Ancient Near East. However, this is a misnomer as these objects have no relationship to the glazed pottery vessels made in Faenza, from which the faience term derives.
Other authors use the terms sintered quartz, glazed frit, frit, composition, Egyptian Blue, paste or (in the 19th century) even porcelain, although the last two terms are very inappropriate as they also describe imitation gems and a type of ceramic. Frit is technically a flux.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The expression 'Pre-Columbian gold' is widely used to describe a range of materials: gold, and gold alloyed with other materials (e.g. copper, silver and platinum).

binding.name: note
binding.literal: See also the Object Name GOURD.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The terms DIORITE, GRANITE and SYENITE have been interchanged incorrectly.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: It is assumed that this term refers mainly to the leaf. The term 'grass does not refer to the classification term 'grass family' but to the non-specialist use of the term.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The dry exudate from a number of plants.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term refers to a stucco with gypsum.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term refers to the fibre.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Hessian is a cloth traditionally made of a mixture of hemp and jute, but the composition may vary according to provenance.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Human remains are defined as whole bodies (or parts of bodies), bones, organs and tissue, as well as hair and nails. The way to retrieve all records for 'human remains' is to search for the term as a Material, rather than as an Object Name.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The Narrow Terms are defined as naturally occurring, although they may in some cases be processed.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term refers to the Egyptian mongoose found in parts of Africa or Europe.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term is only used for samples of the dye. See also INDIGO PLANT for the whole plant or unspecified parts.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: An alloy of iron and nickel (FeNi36) invented in 1896 by Charles Édouard Guillaume for use in horology. Invar has an exceptionally low coefficient of thermal expansion and is therefore ideally suited for use in pendulums where temperature change can affect the timekeeping. The alloy has also been used for making watch balance springs.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: NB. not to be confused with earthenware (ironstone).

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Fibre obtained from Bromelia sylvestris and species of AGAVE used for cordage, nets etc.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: IVORY and its Narrow Terms generally refer to worked material. See also TUSK and its Narrow Terms which generally refer to unworked material. The two terms have been used interchangeably in some records.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: A type of bush vine found in Papua New Guinea.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: A leaf used in Maori plaiting of mats and baskets.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term kurrajong is a local (common) name for the Brachychiton populneus tree (Malvaceae family), which in quite common in inland areas of New South Wales, Australia. Its leaves make good animal fodder, but its pale, spongy wood has limited use. The bark fibres are used for cordage and nets. Early settlers roasted and ground the seeds to make a drink.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term kurrajong is a local (common) name for the Brachychiton populneus tree (Malvaceae family), which in quite common in inland areas of New South Wales, Australia. Its leaves make good animal fodder, but its pale, spongy wood has limited use. There is recorded Aboriginal use of the bark fibres for cordage and nets. Early settlers roasted and ground the seeds to make a drink.

binding.name: note
binding.literal:
A resinous encrustation produced by insects, and used in the East as a scarlet dye. When treated, it is known as 'shellac'. The term lac may have been confused with LACQUER, and it may be necessary to search under both terms. For the Asian collections, objects described as 'lacquer' imply the technique of lacquer application on a substrate, and should have Technique 'lacquered'. Enter the Material 'lacquer (ie. tree resin)' or 'lac' (ie. insect secretion), depending on circumstance. Many objects from South Asia with 'lacquer' in Material may in fact be lacquered using lac.
See also LACQUERED in the Techniques Thesaurus.

binding.name: note
binding.literal:
For the Asian collections, objects described as 'lacquer' imply the technique of lacquer application on a substrate, and should have Technique 'lacquered'. Enter the Material 'lacquer (ie. tree resin)' or 'lac' (ie. insect secretion), depending on circumstance. Many objects from South Asia with 'lacquer' in Material may in fact be lacquered using lac.
See also LACQUERED in the Techniques field.
As a general rule, lacquered objects from the Middle East and South Asia are made using 'lac', while those from South East Asia and the far East are made using 'lacquer'.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: This is an archaic term for brass. It has been retained as a Preferred Term due to its use in the Medieval period, when it was sometimes regarded as a metal distinct from brass.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term has been used interchangeably with FIBRE in some areas of the documentation.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: In this thesaurus, the term has several references, reflecting the documentation: - more specifically, a calcium oxide or calcium carbonate - in a more general sense, a white powdery material which has not been chemically identified and may or may not be 'lime' in the strict sense. - in the records for the Department of Africa, Oceania and the Americas, it usually refers to a substance taken with betel or coca or alternatively to a pigment, and usually made by burning leaves or coral.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: See also records with 'calcium carbonate' in Materials and records with 'stalagmite' or 'stalactite' in Description.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Use the term for the dye. See also MADDER PLANT for the whole plant or unspecified parts.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Nestegis cunninghamii, native of New Zealand.

binding.name: note
binding.literal:
Formerly known as Elenchus purpuratus and now known as Phasianotrochus irisodontes (2012).
Found in South Australia, Victoria and Tasmania.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Cu2(CO3)(OH)2, Copper Carbonate Hydroxide. This is a deep green banded mineral.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term could refer to several materials.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term refers to a kind of thick, stiff pasteboard, originally made of a pulp of old rope, sacking, paper, and other coarse matter milled or rolled with high pressure.

binding.name: note
binding.literal:
Minerals are generally defined in this thesaurus as naturally occurring chemical compounds. Minerals have a 'chemical' name (e.g. 'lead sulphide') and a 'mineral' name (e.g. 'galena') either of which may have been used in the documentation. It has been decided that the 'chemical' name will be the Broad Term.
In order to broaden the scope of searches, certain terms are under both 'mineral' and 'stone'.
N.B.
- Stalagmite and stalagtite are composed of secondary minerals, mainly calcium carbonate, and are closely linked to the formation of limestone.
- The term ‘crystal’ refers to a solid material that has its molecules or atoms or ions in a repeating, ordered (geometric) arrangement. Many different minerals and metals are in crystalline state or form. Although in the absence of a more specific identification, the Material could therefore be 'metal' as well as 'mineral', it is assumed that the latter is more likely, and so the term 'mineral' is entered as a Material.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Nenfro is a highly localised name for a specific rock unit (e.g. Portland Limestone, Hertfordshire Puddingstone), but it is not a geological rock type.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Commom form of Phormium: Phormium tenax (Maori name: harakeke). A group of tender perennials mainly grown for their colourful leaves. These plants, commonly known as New Zealand Flax, are natives of New Zealand. The word Phormium is derived from 'phormos', a basket, and refers to the use of the leaf fibre for basket making; this fibre is also used in the commercial manufacture of ropes and twine.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term refers to any of various seaweeds able to secrete lime.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term encompasses the husk or shell.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Paste made from the fruit of the Atuna racemosa racemosa (Parinarium or Putty Nut) tree, used as an adhesive, filler and caulking.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term refers to the seed.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term refers to the fruit.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Olivene is a term used to describe a variety of green garnet (typically from the Urals).

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Olivine refers to a group of minerals which includes chrysolite (sometimes used to refer to gem quality olivine, which is known also as peridot).

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term refers to the flower.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: A species of willow much used in basket-work.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Osmund is a form of wrought iron.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Use for the whole egg; for the shell, use OSTRICH EGGSHELL.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Also known as the Egg Shell, but in fact a mollusc shell.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: A white metal, resistant to tarnishing. A member of the platinum family of metals.

binding.name: note
binding.literal:
There are over 600 species in the Pandanus genus, but one of the most commonly used species, and most applicable to BM material, is Pandanus tectorius.
Some taxonomists have separated the family Pandanaceae (screw-pine) including the Pandanus species from the Palmae; others see Pandanaceae as part of the extended family of Palmae.

binding.name: note
binding.literal:
There are over 600 species in the Pandanus genus, but one of the most commonly used species, and most applicable to BM material, is Pandanus tectorius.
Some taxonomists have separated the family Pandanaceae (screw-pine) including the Pandanus species from the Palmae; others see Pandanaceae as part of the extended family of Palmae.

binding.name: note
binding.literal:
There are over 600 species in the Pandanus genus, but one of the most commonly used species, and most applicable to BM material, is Pandanus tectorius.
Some taxonomists have separated the family Pandanaceae (screw-pine) including the Pandanus species from the Palmae; others see Pandanaceae as part of the extended family of Palmae.

binding.name: note
binding.literal:
There are over 600 species in the Pandanus genus, but one of the most commonly used species, and most applicable to BM material, is Pandanus tectorius.
Some taxonomists have separated the family Pandanaceae (screw-pine) including the Pandanus species from the Palmae; others see Pandanaceae as part of the extended family of Palmae.

binding.name: note
binding.literal:
There are over 600 species in the Pandanus genus, but one of the most commonly used species, and most applicable to BM material, is Pandanus tectorius.
Some taxonomists have separated the family Pandanaceae (screw-pine) including the Pandanus species from the Palmae; others see Pandanaceae as part of the extended family of Palmae.

binding.name: note
binding.literal:
There are over 600 species in the Pandanus genus, but one of the most commonly used species, and most applicable to BM material, is Pandanus tectorius.
Some taxonomists have separated the family Pandanaceae (screw-pine) including the Pandanus species from the Palmae; others see Pandanaceae as part of the extended family of Palmae.
C.R. Cartwright (25/04/2008)

binding.name: note
binding.literal: A substance prepared from the stem of the papyrus plant. The term is also entered in the Object Name field. For the material not treated in this specific way see PAPYRUS STEM.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: If the the animal type is also known, enter as an additonal entry, e.g. buffalo skin.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: White marble with dark blue, dark red or purple veining (its Italian name alluding to the similarity of the colours of a peacock). Also called Phrygian marble, after the region in Turkey that it comes from, its quarry is located near the town of Afyon.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: If the specific type is known, enter both. e.g. pearlshell and nautilus shell.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Olivine refers to a group of minerals which includes chrysolite (sometimes used to refer to gem quality olivine, which is known also as peridot).

binding.name: note
binding.literal: 'Pig' terms are used as Broad Terms covering wild pigs as well as domesticated varieties.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: 'Pig' terms are used as Broad Terms covering wild pigs as well as domesticated varieties.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: 'Pig' terms are used as Broad Terms covering wild pigs as well as domesticated varieties.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: 'Pig' terms are used as Broad Terms covering wild pigs as well as domesticated varieties.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: 'Pig' terms are used as Broad Terms covering wild pigs as well as domesticated varieties.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: 'Pig' terms are used as Broad Terms covering wild pigs as well as domesticated varieties.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: It is not clear which precise material this term refers to.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: This is an acceptable term for some forms of volcanic glass in Scottish Neolithic.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Leaf of an Australian shrub, used as a narcotic.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Plancheite is a copper silicate mineral.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The Narrow Terms of PLANT SPECIMEN may refer to entire named specimens, or to those for which the documentation did not specify a constituent. The term itself can also be entered in the record as a material referring simply to an unidentified plant.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term used to refer to a mixture of graphite and clay, mainly used for making crucibles.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term refers to a man-made fibre consisting of polyester. It should be used for textiles; in other contexts use polyester or polystyrene.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term refers to the fruit.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Brecciated marble, with yellow, orange, red and dark red spots and veins, on either a pink or a dark red background. Called marmor chium in Roman times, after the island Chios that it comes from, it medieval Italian name alludes to the door’s of St Peter’s church in Rome, whose doors are made of this marble.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: In this thesaurus, the term has two references, reflecting the documentation: - another name for a potassium compound - in a more traditional sense as the ash from burning wood (?) in a pot.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: This term has been used interchangeably with EARTHENWARE and with TERRACOTTA. For the Department of Prehistory and Europe, enter EARTHENWARE instead of POTTERY for post-Medieval collections.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term refers to the fruit.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: This is technically a boundary area between earthenware and stoneware.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: In the UK, the term refers to a specific rock type.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term refers to the fruit.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Atuna racemosa subsp. racemosa Chrysobalanaceae family

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term usually refers to the fibres and stems of a group of climbing palms. Its use has been restricted to the stems.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Rattlesnake tissue includes the snake's rattle, which consists of hollow modified scales from the tip of the snake's tail. When the rattlesnake sheds its skin, a new segment is added to the rattle. After a period of time e.g,. when the rattle has about 7 segments, it can break off and, at this point, might be collected. Or the rattlesnake might be killed (e.g. for food) and its rattle detached deliberately for use as a ritual / musical object.

binding.name: note
binding.literal:
Some reeds are in the Poaceae family, some are not and belong to other families i.e.
Reed is a generic botanical term used to describe numerous tall, grass-like plants of wet places. They are all members of the order Poales and include:
In the Poaceae (grass) family
Common reed, Phragmites australis
Giant reed, Arundo donax
Burma reed, Neyraudia reynaudiana
Reed Canary-grass , Phalaris arundinacea
Reed sweet-grass, Glyceria maxima
Small-reed, Calamagrostis species
In the Cyperaceae (sedge) family
Paper reed or papyrus, Cyperus papyrus
In the Sparganiaceae family
Bur-reed, Sparganium species
In the Typhaceae family
Reed-mace , Typha species, also called bulrush or cattail
In the Restionaceae family
Cape Thatching Reed, Chrondopetalum tectorum, a restio from South Africa.
Thatching Reed, Thamnochortus insignis, a restio from South Africa.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: A horizontally creeping underground stem which bears roots and leaves and usually persists from season to season.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term refers to both natural rubber and synthetic rubber.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term refers to the flower.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term refers to shark skin, ray skin, or similar material wrapped around the wooden core of the hilt (tsuka) and under the cord (tsuka ito) in Japanese swords.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Also search under GUM and RESIN

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Calcium Sodium Aluminum Silicate Carbonate Chloride Sulfate.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: It is assumed that this term refers mainly to the leaf.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Igneous rock with small, light green, rectangular specks within a dark green background. Extremely popular in Roman times, generally called ‘green porphyry’, and quarried near Sparta in Greece.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: In this thesaurus, the term only refers to untanned leather prepared from the skin of the shark.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: This refers to the sheep's skin with the wool on. Use SHEEP SKIN when depilated.

binding.name: note
binding.literal:
The term (which in this thesaurus includes CUTTLEFISH BONE) should not be confused with EGGSHELL.
Mollusc shell may be composed (wholly or in part) of calcite. But also can be composed (wholly or in part) of aragonite and sometimes both together e.g. mussels, with an outer calcite shell and inner aragonite layer (bimineralic shells).

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Satin is a weave structure and so is included, like 'velvet', in the Techniques rather than Materials thesaurus. Both terms, however, are commonly used to describe what an object is made of (or a support). Although in the case of satin, the lustrous effect is often made using silk thread, other fibres can also be used.

binding.name: note
binding.literal:
The term silver-gilt refers to a base of silver to which a layer of gilding has been applied. The Materials entered are 'silver' and 'gold' and the Technique 'gilded'.
For Greek and Roman coins historically referred to as billon or base silver, enter 'base silver' in Description, 'silver' in Materials and 'base' in Materials Comment.
For Medieval coins, enter 'billon' in both Description and Materials.
For any other objects made of base silver, enter 'base silver' in Description and 'silver' in Materials.
.

binding.name: note
binding.literal:
The term hacksilver is an Object Name.
For Greek coins described as made of 'base silver' , the term 'base silver' is entered in Description, and 'silver alloy' in Materials.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term silver-gilt refers to a base of silver to which a layer of gold has been applied. The Technique entered is gilded.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Where the sinew occurs with other types of tissue, use TISSUE or one of its Narrow Terms.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term should not be used for skin with hair. See also FUR.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Molten mixture of lead and tin.

binding.name: note
binding.literal:
The term refers to a combination of minerals, but may have been used as a substitute for MINERAL or its Narrow Terms in the documentation.
In order to broaden the scope of searches, certain terms are under both 'mineral' and 'stone'.
Searches on 'stone' as a Broad Term will include records for objects made of shell because of their calcium carbonate content.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term stonepaste is used in the contex of Islamic ceramics from about 12thC onwards. It describes an artificial ceramic body made from ground quartz with small additions of clay and ground glaze-mixture. The term fritware is also used for this material.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term 'stucco' is used here in a general sense as it can have various meanings, but traditionally refers to a wall coating or render. However, the term also refers to sculptural and artistic use of the material for decoration and figurative representations. Stucco can be of various compositions: it is usually an aggregate of lime and sand, but may be of other compositions. The composition should be specified where known, e.g. lime-stucco or gypsum-stucco, etc. See also the Technique term 'stuccoed'.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Also known as lavulite from South Africa, increasingly used in Southwestern American jewellery.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Synonymous with the 'maple' or Acer pseudoplatanus from the family Aceraceae (For objects from Egypt and elsewhere within the Near and Middle East use 'sycomore fig', unless conclusive evidence to the contrary exists).

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Ficus sycomorus from the family Moraceae. Found in Egypt and elsewhere in the Near and Middle East (previously confused with the 'sycamore', and often recorded as being such, in older documentary sources).

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The terms DIORITE, GRANITE and SYENITE have been interchanged incorrectly.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Use this term - in the absence of a more specific material - for synthetic wool, synthetic caribou sinew, etc. The category includes materials which are, strictly speaking, semi-synthetics.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term should be used for textiles; in other contexts use synthetic or its Narrow Terms.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term refers to any dispersion in water of particles of a polymer (originally synthetic rubber) that is formed in a polymerization process, such as is used as a binder in paints or for coating paper and leather.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term 'taffeta' was applied at different times to different fabrics.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: 'Te ngea' (Pemphis acidula) is a saltbush with very hard wood, and grows very close to the water, mainly on the lagoon shore.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: This term has been used interchangeably with 'fired clay' and 'earthenware'. The term 'terracootta' is never used for vessels.

binding.name: note
binding.literal:
The term is defined in this thesaurus as 'cloth', whether woven, beaten, knitted or otherwise manufactured. If an object is regarded as a textile, but the material term already occurs in this thesaurus under another Broad Term, enter 'textile' in the record as an additional keyword.
Velvet is a technique rather than a textile - please enter 'velvet' into technique and 'textile' in material. Where possible, use the type of textile that has been velveted, eg silk or cotton.
Felt and kesi refer to the finished product, and are neither materials nor techniques (use tapestry for kesi and felted for felt).
See also FIBRE and its Narrow Terms.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Putty created from sap mixed with ash or sawdust, which can then be sculpted.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: This refers to the whole shell or exoskeleton. Use TORTOISE-SHELL for decorative pieces.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: In The Department of Africa, Oceania and the Americas records, the term refers to decorative pieces; for the entire shell or exoskeleton, use TORTOISE CARAPACE.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The suggestion by some authorities to use the term 'travertine' for Egyptian alabaster (ie. calcite) is not generally accepted.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term refers to a milky liquid found in many plants in special vessels called latex tubes or lacticifers. This latex can be used commercially, e.g. Hevea brasiliensis used to produce rubber.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Tufa is a terrestrial rock formed by the crystallising of carbonate minerals, mainly calcite, from water. The terms 'tuff' and 'tufa' have been confused in some areas of the documentation; see also under 'tuff'.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Tuff is a type of volcanic rock, and is formed from ash that is ejected from certain types of volcano during eruptions. The ash forms beds, which when consolidated (solidified) are called ‘tuff’. Depending on the comparative amounts of ash/volcanic glass/rock fragments in the tuff it is called either crystal-, vitreous-, or lithic-tuff. Tuffs can be formed from either ash-fall (e.g. Mount Pinatubo)or ash-flow (e.g. Vesuvius-Pompeii) eruptions. Tuffs are very fine grained rocks (grains usually no bigger than 2mm in diameter).

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term is assumed to refer to the spice or dye, obtained from the rhizome. See also TURMERIC PLANT.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: In the Department of Africa, Oceania and the Americas records, the term refers to decorative pieces. Use TURTLE CARAPACE for the whole shell or exoskeleton.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: TUSK and its Narrow Terms generally refer to unworked material, whereas IVORY and its Narrow Terms generally refer to worked material. The two terms have been used interchangeably in some records.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term refers to fossilized wood.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: See also VARNISHED in the Techniques Thesaurus.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: To cover such terms as Shea butter.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term applies to a fabric having the appearance or surface of velvet, but made from cotton or synthetic yarn in place of silk. The specific material should also be entered where known.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Virenium is a patented silver-coloured base metal alloy in the Nickel Silver family, often used for commemorative coins and medals. Composed largely of copper, with nickel, zinc and other constituents. Intended to have the look and stability of precious metal. Used in high denomination coinage since 1978. Trademark of Pobjoy Mint Ltd.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term is used here to cover all geological materials, including ash and lava, formed through external volcanic processes.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term refers to the nut.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: See also ivory - although not strictly the same material as whalebone/baleen, may be of interest.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: This term could refer to PEWTER, TIN, SILVER ALLOY, etc.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: A term used for a white material, usually of shell, but sometimes imitated in bone or composition, and used for decorative bosses and discs on Anglo-Saxon and Dark Age jewellery.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term refers to the wood.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Although felt may not be made entirely of wool, wool is a major constituent. Any additional materials are entered where known.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term refers to the wood.
